title: Society for Quantitative Analysis of Behavior
text: The Society for the Quantitative Analyses of Behavior was founded in 1978 by <a href="Michael%20Commons">Michael Lamport Commons</a> and <a href="John%20Anthony%20Nevin">John Anthony Nevin</a>. The first president was <a href="Richard%20Herrnstein">Richard J. Herrnstein</a>. In the beginning it was called the Harvard Symposium on Quantitative Analysis of Behavior (HSQAB). This society meets once a year to discuss various topic in <a href="quantitative%20analysis%20of%20behavior">quantitative analysis of behavior</a> including: <a href="behavioral%20economics">behavioral economics</a>, <a href="behavioral%20momentum">behavioral momentum</a>, <a href="Connectionist">Connectionist</a> systems or <a href="neural%20networks">neural networks</a>, <a href="hyperbolic%20discounting">hyperbolic discounting</a>, <a href="foraging">foraging</a>, <a href="errorless%20learning">errorless learning</a>, <a href="learning">learning</a> and the <a href="Rescorla-Wagner%20model">Rescorla-Wagner model</a>, <a href="matching%20law">matching law</a>, <a href="Melioration%20theory">Melioration</a>, <a href="scalar%20expectancy">scalar expectancy</a>, <a href="Detection%20theory">signal detection</a> and <a href="stimulus%20control">stimulus control</a>, <a href="connectionism">connectionism</a> or <a href="Artificial%20neural%20network">Neural Network</a>s. Mathematical models and data are presented and discussed. The field is a branch of <a href="mathematical%20psychology">mathematical psychology</a>. Some papers resulting from the symposium are published as a special issue of the journal "<a href="Behavioural%20Processes">Behavioural Processes</a>".
